title: Observing How the Universe Changed over Time

previous.title: Estimating the Size of the Observable Universe

next.title: The Large-Scale Structure of the Universe

content:
The distribution and concentration of matter in the Universe for sizes larger than a galaxy is called the large-scale structure of the Universe. Astronomers can measure the distance to billions of galaxies using data from Rubin Observatory. Using the distances and position of galaxies, astronomers can create a map of the observable Universe that reveals this large-scale structure.

Here is a series of maps that show the galaxies detected by Rubin Observatory at certain distances away from Earth. The distances are expressed as redshift numbers. Lower redshift numbers are closer to Earth, and higher redshift numbers represent farther distances. Each map can be thought of as a view back to a particular time in the history of the Universeâ€”at greater distances we see the Universe as it was at earlier times.

Switch between the different redshift ranges to explore how the Universe has changed over time. Try zooming and dragging the maps for a closer look.

question.title: Question #1
question.label: Look at the map of the farthest distance. Does this map represent a time long ago (early in the Universe) or a recent time (later in the history of the Universe)?

question.title: Question #2
question.label: Look at the map of the closest distance. Does this map represent a time long ago (early in the Universe) or a recent time (later in the history of the Universe)?

question.title: Question #3
question.label: Describe how the distribution of galaxies in the Universe has changed over time. When were large numbers of galaxies clumped together (more concentrated) in some places? When were galaxies distributed more evenly?
